Situation1: Help each other in times of need or emotional distress.
Expectation2: Stay updated on changes in laws and legal precedents.
Situation2: An attorney in a case before you has just cited a new appellate court decision from last week that could be relevant. You need to review it before the next session.
Story: My phone buzzed just as I was gathering the files for tomorrow’s hearing. It was my brother, his voice trembling, asking if I could come over. He’d just broken up with his long-term girlfriend and sounded completely shattered. As his sister, I knew he needed me—he’d always been there for me, and I’d promised to do the same. But as I hung up, my eyes fell on the thick printout of the new appellate court decision the attorney had cited today. I hadn’t read it yet, and the next session was in the morning. As a judge, I was expected to be fully prepared, to know the latest legal precedents inside and out. The weight of both roles pressed on me: my brother’s pain, my duty to the court. I paced the living room, torn between the urge to rush to my brother’s side and the responsibility to uphold the integrity of my courtroom. My heart ached with the knowledge that, whatever I chose, I would be letting someone down.
